headers.full: The Coefficient Matrix of a System of Linear Equations
headers.toc: The Coefficient Matrix of a System of Linear Equations

intro.para:
We are now going to learn how to work with systems of linear equations more economically. Observe that, when reducing a system of linear equations to
RREF
RREF = Row Reduced Echelon Form , we really only manipulate its coefficients, not its variables. So, by carrying the variables along all the time we just do a lot of unnecessary work. – How can we do better?

We save ourselves a lot of work by extracting from the system its coefficients and writing them in a rectangle whose rows and columns resemble the original system. Thus we obtain the (augmented) coefficient matrix of the given system of linear equations. Now the operations on equations in a system translate into operations on rows in the associated augmented coefficient matrix. The details follow.

section.body.para: To find the solutions of a system of linear equations, we turn its augmented coefficient matrix into a matrix in RREF. To this end we apply row operations to the augmented coefficient matrix which correspond to operations on the rows of a system of linear equations. Here is the dictionary which translates between these two settings.

def.para: The rank of a system of linear equations is the number of leading 1’s in the RREF of its non-augmented coefficient matrix.
